image.altText: An Indigenous lady wipes away tears from her face with a tissue

items.synopsis: The mother of teenager Cleveland Dodd, who became WA's first youth to die in custody, expresses disappointment with Corrective Services Minister Paul Papalia over revelations uncovered by the ABC about what happened the night he was found unconscious in his cell.

title.children: 'He told a big lie': Cleveland Dodd's mother accuses Minister of dishonesty over his death in custody

image.altText: Michelle Bullock speaks at a podium with branding behind her. She is gesturing with her hand.

items.synopsis: Interest rates hit a 12-year high as the Reserve Bank resumes hiking, with a 0.25 percentage point rise taking the cash rate to 4.35 per cent.

title.children: The RBA has raised interest rates, despite 'the economy showing more signs that it is weakening'

image.altText: A police officers stands looking at a breathalyser screen, alongside a tow-truck driver on the side of a busy road.

items.synopsis: Seven tow trucks are impounded and a total of 26 charges are laid during a major police operation targeting unlawful activity in Perth's tow-truck industry.

title.children: Crackdown on tow-truck industry sees 17 people charged, with police alleging links to bikie gangs

image.altText: Anthony Albanese shakes hands with Xi Jinping in front of the Australian and Chiense flags in Beijing.

items.synopsis: Anthony Albanese is wrapping up in China after a whirlwind three-day trip aimed at stabilising ties between the two countries. From an invite to Australia to symbolism and plenty of talk about friendship, these are the key takeaways from the visit.

title.children: 'A handsome boy from Australia' and an invite for the president: The key takeaways from Albanese's China visit

image.altText: A man pictured from behind in a black hooded jumper

items.synopsis: Morris Leonard Deale has been found guilty of multiple indecent assaults that occurred over a number of years in Western Australia.

title.children: Church member who believed homosexuality to be a sin found guilty of molesting seven men

image.altText: A drone shot of rows of houses in Shell Cove, Wollongong's south.

items.synopsis: Tell us your loan size, term and interest rate, and our mortgage repayment calculator will work out how much extra you may have to pay on your loan.

title.children: How much extra could your mortgage repayments be, now that the cash rate is 4.35 per cent?

image.altText: side view of a crashed where two boys who were passengers died in  the Sydney south-west suburb of Ashcroft

items.synopsis: Two boys aged 13 and 14 were killed when a grey Ford sedan hit a telegraph pole in the city's south-west.

title.children: Two men arrested over involvement in Sydney car crash that killed teenage boys

image.altText: William Tyrrell's fost father walks out of court mobbed by reporters

items.synopsis: A judge rules the allegations the man, who can't be named, lied to the secretive commission were based on questions that were "too ambiguous".

title.children: William Tyrrell's foster father found not guilty of lying to NSW Crime Commission

image.altText: Silhouette of man and child with southern lights

items.synopsis: An aurora australis visible to the naked eye has been seen across Western Australia in the brightest display of southern lights in years.

title.children: Aurora australis 'brighter than in Antarctica' seen across WA

image.altText: Australian Eastern Brown Snake coiled on sand in the bright sunshine.

items.synopsis: The 25-year-old French man died following a suspected brown snake bite while working as a grain harvest casual in north-west Victoria.

title.children: Backpacker dies after suspected snakebite at Mallee grain depot

image.altText: People walk around in rubble in Gaza

items.synopsis: Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu has said Israel plans to have “overall security responsibility” in Gaza “for an indefinite period” after its war with Hamas. Follow live.

title.children: Netanyahu says Israel plans to have 'overall security responsibility' in Gaza after war

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Russia's foreign ministry says a remark by an Israeli junior minister who appeared to express openness to the idea of Israel carrying out a nuclear strike on Gaza raises concerns. Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu on Sunday suspended Heritage Minister Amihay Eliyahu, from a far-right party in the coalition government, from cabinet meetings "until further notice". Asked in a radio interview about a hypothetical nuclear option, Mr Eliyahu had replied: "That's one way." "This has raised a huge number of questions," Maria Zakharova, Russia's foreign ministry spokeswoman, was quoted as saying by state RIA news agency. Ms Zakharova said the main issue was Israel appeared to have admit it has nuclear weapons. Israel does not publicly acknowledge it has nuclear weapons though the Federation of American Scientists estimates Israel has about 90 nuclear warheads. "Question number one — it turns out that we are hearing official statements about the presence of nuclear weapons?" Ms Zakharova said. The remark by Mr Eliyahu has drawn condemnation from around the Arab world, scandalised mainstream Israeli broadcasters, and been deemed "objectionable" by a US official. Reuters
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Israeli nuclear remark raises 'huge number of questions', says Russia

children.content: Russia's foreign ministry says a remark by an Israeli junior minister who appeared to express openness to the idea of Israel carrying out a nuclear strike on Gaza raises concerns.
Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu on Sunday suspended Heritage Minister Amihay Eliyahu, from a far-right party in the coalition government, from cabinet meetings "until further notice".
Asked in a radio interview about a hypothetical nuclear option, Mr Eliyahu had replied: "That's one way."
"This has raised a huge number of questions," Maria Zakharova, Russia's foreign ministry spokeswoman, was quoted as saying by state RIA news agency.
Ms Zakharova said the main issue was Israel appeared to have admit it has nuclear weapons.
Israel does not publicly acknowledge it has nuclear weapons though the Federation of American Scientists estimates Israel has about 90 nuclear warheads.
"Question number one — it turns out that we are hearing official statements about the presence of nuclear weapons?" Ms Zakharova said.
The remark by Mr Eliyahu has drawn condemnation from around the Arab world, scandalised mainstream Israeli broadcasters, and been deemed "objectionable" by a US official.
Reuters

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: We just heard from retired army general and analyst Mick Ryan about why Israeli forces are infiltrating northern Gaza first. He also says it's "very unlikely" Israel will want to return to a long-term occupation of Gaza. "They tried that before, they found it didn't work well so I don't think that is what they are talking about in a long-term presence," he told ABC News Afternoons. "We are talking about a smaller presence and collecting information [and] ensuring that they are not able to be surprised again." Israeli Prime Minister Benjam Netanyahu says Israel will have "overall security responsibility" over Gaza for an indefinite period.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Unlikely Israel will want return to 'long-term occupation' of Gaza

children.content: We
just heard
from retired army general and analyst Mick Ryan about why Israeli forces are infiltrating northern Gaza first.
He also says it's "very unlikely" Israel will want to return to a long-term occupation of Gaza.
"They tried that before, they found it didn't work well so I don't think that is what they are talking about in a long-term presence," he told ABC News Afternoons.
"We are talking about a smaller presence and collecting information [and] ensuring that they are not able to be surprised again."
Israeli Prime Minister Benjam Netanyahu says Israel will have
"overall security responsibility"
over Gaza for an indefinite period.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext:
Defence Minister Richard Marles has reiterated Australia's position on calling for a "pause" to allow humanitarian aid into Gaza. "We have made clear the right that Israel has to defend itself in the face of the 
attacks that were undertaken by Hamas back on the 7 October and obviously those attacks were directed at innocent people", he told the ABC's Afternoon Briefing. "We have also been really concerned about the humanitarian situation in Gaza, about the plight of innocent 
Palestinians, the vast bulk of whom have nothing to do with Hamas," he said. "And it is really important that front and centre in terms of the way in which Israel goes about its work is the safety of innocent Palestinians in Gaza. "That is why we have been 
calling for humanitarian assistance to be allowed into Gaza. It is why we have been calling for a pause to allow for humanitarian assistance to be provided and we will continue to advocate on behalf of the humanitarian issues which are impacting Gazans." When asked about the legal action launched by Palestinian humanitarian groups to access records on Australia's arms exports to Israel, and whether Australia had provided weapons to Israel since October 7, Marles said the matters are before the courts and he would not go "into details". "But let me simply say, Israel has not sought any weapons from Australia, and we have not provided any", he said.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Marles says Australia has not provided weapons to Israel since October 7, reiterates position on humanitarian 'pause'

children.content: Defence Minister Richard Marles
has reiterated Australia's position on calling for a "pause" to allow humanitarian aid into Gaza.

"We have made clear the right that Israel has to defend itself in the face of the 
attacks that were undertaken by Hamas back on the 7 October and obviously those attacks were directed at innocent people", he told the ABC's Afternoon Briefing.

"We have also been really concerned about the humanitarian situation in Gaza, about the plight of innocent 
Palestinians, the vast bulk of whom have nothing to do with Hamas," he said.
"And it is really important that front and centre in terms of the way in which Israel goes about its work is the safety of innocent Palestinians in Gaza.

"That is why we have been 
calling for humanitarian assistance to be allowed into Gaza. It is why we have been calling for a pause to allow for humanitarian assistance to be provided and we will continue to advocate on behalf of the humanitarian issues which are impacting Gazans."
When asked about the legal action launched

by Palestinian humanitarian groups to access records on Australia's arms exports to Israel, and whether Australia had provided weapons to Israel since October 7, Marles said the matters are before the courts and he would not go "into details".
"But let me simply say, Israel has not sought any weapons from Australia, and we have not provided any", he said.

image.altText: Men attempt to pull a girl out from beneath rubble.

items.synopsis: IDF operations in Gaza will deal a lethal blow to Hamas, but destroying the group requires long-term political and social remedies that eliminate the reasons why young men in Gaza feel a need to join, writes Mick Ryan.

title.children: To eliminate Hamas, Israel will need to address the reasons young men in Gaza are joining the group

image.altText: Donald Trump sits behind a laptop in a courtroom. He is frowning.

items.synopsis: Donald Trump repeatedly clashes with a New York judge during a hostile and rambling court appearance in the fraud trial that threatens the future of his real estate empire.

title.children: Trump angers judge during fiery New York fraud trial testimony

image.altText: A man wearing a collared work shirt takes a selfie in a mirror

items.synopsis: Reid Partlett, 20, will spend at least three years behind bars for injuring two people in a random nail gun shooting on the M1 motorway on the NSW Central Coast in January.

title.children: Man to spend three years behind bars for firing nail gun at cars on M1 motorway

image.altText: Parents and babies on a tiny mock-up race track

items.synopsis: The only qualifying rule for little humans participating in the annual race is that they have to be wearing a nappy, with mood and nap times coming into play for those trying to guess a winner.

title.children: Forget the Melbourne Cup, the annual Diaper Derby brings enough tears and laughs for Exmouth parents

image.altText: Mark Zahra kisses the Melbourne Cup

items.synopsis: Mark Zahra answers the critics for his choice in rides, becoming the first jockey in 44 years to win back-to-back Melbourne Cups on different horses, as Without A Fight beats the field at Flemington.

title.children: 'I told you so': Mark Zahra makes history with Melbourne Cup win on Without A Fight

image.altText: Delta Goodrem wearing yellow against a green backdrop at the Melbourne Cup.

items.synopsis: Tens of thousands of punters descended on the Flemington Racecourse for the running of the 2023 Melbourne Cup — the 163rd iteration of the historic race.

title.children: Fashion and footraces at Flemington as crowds exceed 80,000 at the 2023 Melbourne Cup

image.altText: The top half of a gold trophy with Melbourne Cup 2023 engraved on it

items.synopsis: Check out the full finishing order from the 2023 Melbourne Cup.

title.children: The complete Melbourne Cup finishing order from first to last

image.altText: Alicia Molik looks on

items.synopsis: Australia is left with just three players ahead of Australia's opening Billie Jean King Cup tie after a "scheduling disaster" leaves the best doubles players in Mexico.

title.children: 'Anyone got a private jet?': Australian star 'punished' by WTA 'scheduling disaster'

image.altText: Top view of a glass of orange juice.

items.synopsis: Questions are being raised about the system for prescribing "takeaway" methadone following the tragic death of a six-year-old in New South Wales, who drank orange juice mixed with the opioid replacement medication.

title.children: Boy died after drinking orange juice mixed with mother's 'takeaway' methadone, inquest hears

image.altText: A woman with blonde hair and a white shirt looking angry.

items.synopsis: A 48-year-old woman accused of operating a puppy farm in Adelaide's north while on a good behaviour bond over previous animal cruelty offences will contest the new charges, a court has heard.

title.children: Convicted puppy farmer denies new charges after RSPCA seizes 86 dogs

image.altText: A composite image of a father and son, and a couple and their daughter

items.synopsis: The five people killed in a crash at a pub in regional Victoria on Sunday night have been identified as members of two families in Melbourne's outer suburbs.

title.children: 'A pure, lovely soul': Melbourne families identified as victims in horror crash in Victorian town

image.altText: Albanese's hair sticks up in the wind as he walks past a Chinese temple

items.synopsis: Xi Jinping chose a Chinese proverb about gratitude to welcome Anthony Albanese to Beijing — a reference to diplomatic ties forged by Gough Whitlam. But 50 years later another is equally apt: let sleeping dogs lie, writes David Speers.

title.children: Two proverbs tell the story of two leaders trying to put bygones behind them

image.altText: A smiling older woman in front of a birthday cake bearing the numerals "110". She is surrounded by her family.

items.synopsis: Dulcie Fawcett was born in SA in 1913 and moved to WA at the dawn of her teenage years. One of her daughters says the secret to her mum's longevity was hard work and moderation.

title.children: WA's oldest woman dies three months before 111th birthday

image.altText: A completely solid gold toilet

items.synopsis: Police believe the 18-carat commode may never be recovered.

title.children: Four men charged over 2019 disappearance of $9 million golden toilet

image.altText: Three horses with jockeys run down the straight on a racetrack

items.synopsis: Do horses even know they are in a race, let alone have a desire to win it? Do they understand what it means when their nose is the first one to pass the post?

title.children: The truth about what horses think about being raced

image.altText: Close up image of lamb and other meat in a cabinet at a butcher

items.synopsis: Farmers battling a significant slump in sheep prices say supermarkets are ripping off consumers, as Woolworths announces it will cut its lamb prices by 20 per cent.

title.children: Supermarket lamb prices to fall but farmer frustration remains

image.altText: Woman with black curly hair smiles in front of wall with colourful painting.

items.synopsis: The 51-year-old needs 'urgent medical care' according to her family but was refused a hospital transfer because she wouldn't wear a hijab.

title.children: Jailed Iranian activist, Nobel Peace Prize winner begins hunger strike

image.altText: Anthony Albanese and Li Qiang shake hands against a blue backdrop.

items.synopsis: An audit of the Australian Government Future Fund identifies investments in at least 50 high risk Chinese companies linked to the Communist Party and oppression of Uyghurs in Xinjiang.

title.children: Taxpayer funds invested in dozens of high risk Chinese companies through federal government fund, new audit reveals

image.altText: Palestinians mourn relatives killed in the Israeli bombardment of the Gaza Strip.

items.synopsis: The Gaza health ministry says more than 4,100 children have been killed since October 7, as the Pentagon admits to "thousands" of civilians killed.

title.children: UN leader says Gaza is a 'graveyard for children' with estimates of more than 4,100 killed

image.altText: A floating windfarm

items.synopsis: The editor of a prominent scientific journal has described online claims about a study linking whale deaths to offshore wind farms as a "classic example" of misinformation as concerns grow about fake news distorting the debate.

title.children: Editor of scientific journal blasts 'imaginary paper' linking offshore wind farms to whale deaths

image.altText: Close up of green capers covered with salt

items.synopsis: Australian-grown capers are a sought-after ingredient for high-end restaurants, selling for up to $50 per 250 grams. And with each tiny bud picked by hand, it's not hard to see why.

title.children: Capers look effortless and appetising on a plate — but harvesting them is a brutal labour of love
